column15: A larger event of which this particular procedure is a component or step.
column16: The MedicationAdministration resource has a partOf reference to Procedure, but this is not a circular reference.   For example, the anesthesia MedicationAdministration is part of the surgical Procedure (MedicationAdministration.partOf = Procedure).  For example, the procedure to insert the IV port for an IV medication administration is part of the medication administration (Procedure.partOf = MedicationAdministration).
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: preparation | in-progress | not-done | on-hold | stopped | completed | entered-in-error | unknown
column15: A code specifying the state of the procedure. Generally, this will be the in-progress or completed state.
column16:
The "unknown" code is not to be used to convey other statuses.  The "unknown" code should be used when one of the statuses applies, but the authoring system doesn't know the current state of the procedure.

This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: Captures the reason for the current state of the procedure.
column16: This is generally only used for "exception" statuses such as "not-done", "suspended" or "aborted". The reason for performing the event at all is captured in reasonCode, not here.
column27: A code that identifies the reason a procedure was not performed.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: A code that classifies the procedure for searching, sorting and display purposes (e.g. "Surgical Procedure").
column27: A code that classifies a procedure for searching, sorting and display purposes.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: The specific procedure that is performed. Use text if the exact nature of the procedure cannot be coded (e.g. "Laparoscopic Appendectomy").
column17: 0..1 to account for primarily narrative only resources.
column27: Codes describing the type of  Procedure
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: Who the procedure was performed on
column15: The person, animal or group on which the procedure was performed.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: The Encounter during which this Procedure was created or performed or to which the creation of this record is tightly associated.
column16: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some activities may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: Estimated or actual date, date-time, period, or age when the procedure was performed.  Allows a period to support complex procedures that span more than one date, and also allows for the length of the procedure to be captured.
column16: Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the procedure was performed. Range is generally used when the patient reports an age range when the procedure was performed, such as sometime between 20-25 years old.  dateTime supports a range of precision due to some procedures being reported as past procedures that might not have millisecond precision while other procedures performed and documented during the encounter might have more precise UTC timestamps with timezone.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: Individual who recorded the record and takes responsibility for its content.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: Individual who is making the procedure statement.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: The people who performed the procedure
column15: Limited to "real" people rather than equipment.

column17: A reference to Device supports use cases, such as pacemakers.

column14: Organization the device or practitioner was acting for
column15: The organization the device or practitioner was acting on behalf of.

column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: The location where the procedure actually happened.  E.g. a newborn at home, a tracheostomy at a restaurant.
column17: Ties a procedure to where the records are likely kept.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: The coded reason why the procedure was performed. This may be a coded entity of some type, or may simply be present as text.
column16: Use Procedure.reasonCode when a code sufficiently describes the reason.  Use Procedure.reasonReference when referencing a resource, which allows more information to be conveyed, such as onset date. Procedure.reasonCode and Procedure.reasonReference are not meant to be duplicative.  For a single reason, either Procedure.reasonCode or Procedure.reasonReference can be used.  Procedure.reasonCode may be a summary code, or Procedure.reasonReference may be used to reference a very precise definition of the reason using Condition | Observation | Procedure | DiagnosticReport | DocumentReference.  Both Procedure.reasonCode and Procedure.reasonReference can be used if they are describing different reasons for the procedure.
column27: A code that identifies the reason a procedure is  required.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: The justification that the procedure was performed
column15: The justification of why the procedure was performed.
column16:
It is possible for a procedure to be a reason (such as C-Section) for another procedure (such as an epidural). Other examples include endoscopy for dilatation and biopsy (a combination of diagnostic and therapeutic use). 
Use Procedure.reasonCode when a code sufficiently describes the reason.  Use Procedure.reasonReference when referencing a resource, which allows more information to be conveyed, such as onset date. Procedure.reasonCode and Procedure.reasonReference are not meant to be duplicative.  For a single reason, either Procedure.reasonCode or Procedure.reasonReference can be used.  Procedure.reasonCode may be a summary code, or Procedure.reasonReference may be used to reference a very precise definition of the reason using Condition | Observation | Procedure | DiagnosticReport | DocumentReference.  Both Procedure.reasonCode and Procedure.reasonReference can be used if they are describing different reasons for the procedure.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: Detailed and structured anatomical location information. Multiple locations are allowed - e.g. multiple punch biopsies of a lesion.

column27: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: The outcome of the procedure - did it resolve the reasons for the procedure being performed?
column16: If outcome contains narrative text only, it can be captured using the CodeableConcept.text.
column27: An outcome of a procedure - whether it was resolved or otherwise.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: Any report resulting from the procedure
column15: This could be a histology result, pathology report, surgical report, etc.
column16: There could potentially be multiple reports - e.g. if this was a procedure which took multiple biopsies resulting in a number of anatomical pathology reports.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: Any complications that occurred during the procedure, or in the immediate post-performance period. These are generally tracked separately from the notes, which will typically describe the procedure itself rather than any 'post procedure' issues.
column16: If complications are only expressed by the narrative text, they can be captured using the CodeableConcept.text.
column27: Codes describing complications that resulted from a procedure.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: Any complications that occurred during the procedure, or in the immediate post-performance period.
column17: This is used to document a condition that is a result of the procedure, not the condition that was the reason for the procedure.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: If the procedure required specific follow up - e.g. removal of sutures. The follow up may be represented as a simple note or could potentially be more complex, in which case the CarePlan resource can be used.
column27: Specific follow up required for a procedure e.g. removal of sutures.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: Any other notes and comments about the procedure.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column16: CDA Document Id extension and root.

column15: A set of Security-Tag codes specifying the level of privacy/security of the Document. Note that DocumentReference.meta.security contains the security labels of the "reference" to the document, while DocumentReference.securityLabel contains a snapshot of the security labels on the document the reference refers to.
column16:
The confidentiality codes can carry multiple vocabulary items. HL7 has developed an understanding of security and privacy tags that might be desirable in a Document Sharing environment, called HL7 Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System (HCS). The following specification is recommended but not mandated, as the vocabulary bindings are an administrative domain responsibility. The use of this method is up to the policy domain such as the XDS Affinity Domain or other Trust Domain where all parties including sender and recipients are trusted to appropriately tag and enforce.   

In the HL7 Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification (HCS) there are code systems specific to Confidentiality, Sensitivity, Integrity, and Handling Caveats. Some values would come from a local vocabulary as they are related to workflow roles and special projects.
column17: Use of the Health Care Privacy/Security Classification (HCS) system of security-tag use is recommended.
column27: Security Labels from the Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System.

column16: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

column14: Who and/or what the observation is about
column15: The patient, or group of patients, location, or device this observation is about and into whose record the observation is placed. If the actual focus of the observation is different from the subject (or a sample of, part, or region of the subject), the `focus` element or the `code` itself specifies the actual focus of the observation.
column16: One would expect this element to be a cardinality of 1..1. The only circumstance in which the subject can be missing is when the observation is made by a device that does not know the patient. In this case, the observation SHALL be matched to a patient through some context/channel matching technique, and at this point, the observation should be updated.

column3: US Core Pediatric BMI for Age Observation Profile
column14: What the observation is about, when it is not about the subject of record
column15: The actual focus of an observation when it is not the patient of record representing something or someone associated with the patient such as a spouse, parent, fetus, or donor. For example, fetus observations in a mother's record.  The focus of an observation could also be an existing condition,  an intervention, the subject's diet,  another observation of the subject,  or a body structure such as tumor or implanted device.   An example use case would be using the Observation resource to capture whether the mother is trained to change her child's tracheostomy tube. In this example, the child is the patient of record and the mother is the focus.
column16: Typically, an observation is made about the subject - a patient, or group of patients, location, or device - and the distinction between the subject and what is directly measured for an observation is specified in the observation code itself ( e.g., "Blood Glucose") and does not need to be represented separately using this element.  Use `specimen` if a reference to a specimen is required.  If a code is required instead of a resource use either  `bodysite` for bodysites or the standard extension [focusCode](http://hl7.org/fhir/extension-observation-focuscode.html).

column3: US Core Pediatric BMI for Age Observation Profile
column15: Provides a reason why the expected value in the element Observation.value[x] is missing.
column16:
Null or exceptional values can be represented two ways in FHIR Observations.  One way is to simply include them in the value set and represent the exceptions in the value.  For example, measurement values for a serology test could be  "detected", "not detected", "inconclusive", or  "specimen unsatisfactory".   

The alternate way is to use the value element for actual observations and use the explicit dataAbsentReason element to record exceptional values.  For example, the dataAbsentReason code "error" could be used when the measurement was not completed. Note that an observation may only be reported if there are values to report. For example differential cell counts values may be reported only when > 0.  Because of these options, use-case agreements are required to interpret general observations for null or exceptional values.
column17: For many results it is necessary to handle exceptional values in measurements.

column15: Provides a reason why the expected value in the element Observation.component.value[x] is missing.
column16:
"Null" or exceptional values can be represented two ways in FHIR Observations.  One way is to simply include them in the value set and represent the exceptions in the value.  For example, measurement values for a serology test could be  "detected", "not detected", "inconclusive", or  "test not done". 

The alternate way is to use the value element for actual observations and use the explicit dataAbsentReason element to record exceptional values.  For example, the dataAbsentReason code "error" could be used when the measurement was not completed.  Because of these options, use-case agreements are required to interpret general observations for exceptional values.
column17: For many results it is necessary to handle exceptional values in measurements.
column27: Codes specifying why the result (`Observation.value[x]`) is missing.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Pediatric BMI for Age Observation Profile
column15: A categorical assessment of an observation value.  For example, high, low, normal.
column16: Historically used for laboratory results (known as 'abnormal flag' ),  its use extends to other use cases where coded interpretations  are relevant.  Often reported as one or more simple compact codes this element is often placed adjacent to the result value in reports and flow sheets to signal the meaning/normalcy status of the result.
column17: For some results, particularly numeric results, an interpretation is necessary to fully understand the significance of a result.
column27: Codes identifying interpretations of observations.

column3: US Core Pediatric BMI for Age Observation Profile
column14: Provides guide for interpretation of component result
column15: Guidance on how to interpret the value by comparison to a normal or recommended range.
column16: Most observations only have one generic reference range. Systems MAY choose to restrict to only supplying the relevant reference range based on knowledge about the patient (e.g., specific to the patient's age, gender, weight and other factors), but this might not be possible or appropriate. Whenever more than one reference range is supplied, the differences between them SHOULD be provided in the reference range and/or age properties.
column17: Knowing what values are considered "normal" can help evaluate the significance of a particular result. Need to be able to provide multiple reference ranges for different contexts.

column15: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.

column14: A set of rules under which this content was created
column15: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
column16: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

column15: The base language in which the resource is written.
column16: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

column14: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
column15: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
column16: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
column16: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. column17: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type.

column16: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: The base language in which the resource is written.
column16: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).
column27: A human language.

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column14: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
column15: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
column16: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

column39: OBX.21  For OBX segments from systems without OBX-21 support a combination of ORC/OBR and OBX must be negotiated between trading partners to uniquely identify the OBX segment. Depending on how V2 has been implemented each of these may be an option: 1) OBR-3 + OBX-3 + OBX-4 or 2) OBR-3 + OBR-4 + OBX-3 + OBX-4 or 2) some other way to uniquely ID the OBR/ORC + OBX-3 + OBX-4.

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: A plan, proposal or order that is fulfilled in whole or in part by this event.  For example, a MedicationRequest may require a patient to have laboratory test performed before  it is dispensed.
column17: Allows tracing of authorization for the event and tracking whether proposals/recommendations were acted upon.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: A larger event of which this particular Observation is a component or step.  For example,  an observation as part of a procedure.
column16: To link an Observation to an Encounter use `encounter`.  See the  [Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#obsgrouping) below for guidance on referencing another Observation.

column16: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.
column17: Need to track the status of individual results. Some results are finalized before the whole report is finalized.
column27: Codes providing the status of an observation.

column41: status  Amended & Final are differentiated by whether it is the subject of a ControlAct event with a type of "revise"

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: A code that classifies the general type of observation being made.
column16: In addition to the required category valueset, this element allows various categorization schemes based on the owner’s definition of the category and effectively multiple categories can be used at once.  The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set.
column17: Used for filtering what observations are retrieved and displayed.
column27: Codes for high level observation categories.

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: The name of the imaging test performed on a patient.  A LOINC **SHALL** be used if the concept is present in LOINC.
column16: The typical patterns for codes are:  1)  a LOINC code either as a  translation from a "local" code or as a primary code, or 2)  a local code only if no suitable LOINC exists,  or 3)  both the local and the LOINC translation.   Systems SHALL be capable of sending the local code if one exists.  When using LOINC , Use either the SHORTNAME or LONG_COMMON_NAME field for the display.
column17: Knowing what kind of observation is being made is essential to understanding the observation.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column14: Who and/or what the observation is about
column15: The patient, or group of patients, location, or device this observation is about and into whose record the observation is placed. If the actual focus of the observation is different from the subject (or a sample of, part, or region of the subject), the `focus` element or the `code` itself specifies the actual focus of the observation.
column16: One would expect this element to be a cardinality of 1..1. The only circumstance in which the subject can be missing is when the observation is made by a device that does not know the patient. In this case, the observation SHALL be matched to a patient through some context/channel matching technique, and at this point, the observation should be updated.
column17: Observations have no value if you don't know who or what they're about.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column14: What the observation is about, when it is not about the subject of record
column15: The actual focus of an observation when it is not the patient of record representing something or someone associated with the patient such as a spouse, parent, fetus, or donor. For example, fetus observations in a mother's record.  The focus of an observation could also be an existing condition,  an intervention, the subject's diet,  another observation of the subject,  or a body structure such as tumor or implanted device.   An example use case would be using the Observation resource to capture whether the mother is trained to change her child's tracheostomy tube. In this example, the child is the patient of record and the mother is the focus.
column16: Typically, an observation is made about the subject - a patient, or group of patients, location, or device - and the distinction between the subject and what is directly measured for an observation is specified in the observation code itself ( e.g., "Blood Glucose") and does not need to be represented separately using this element.  Use `specimen` if a reference to a specimen is required.  If a code is required instead of a resource use either  `bodysite` for bodysites or the standard extension [focusCode](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-observation-focuscode.html).
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column14: Healthcare event during which this observation is made
column15: The healthcare event  (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) during which this observation is made.
column16: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some events may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter (e.g. pre-admission laboratory tests).
column17: For some observations it may be important to know the link between an observation and a particular encounter.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: The time or time-period the observed value is asserted as being true. For biological subjects - e.g. human patients - this is usually called the "physiologically relevant time". This is usually either the time of the procedure or of specimen collection, but very often the source of the date/time is not known, only the date/time itself.
column16: At least a date should be present unless this observation is a historical report.  For recording imprecise or "fuzzy" times (For example, a blood glucose measurement taken "after breakfast") use the [Timing](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/datatypes.html#timing) datatype which allow the measurement to be tied to regular life events.
column17: Knowing when an observation was deemed true is important to its relevance as well as determining trends.
column37:
ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}
us-core-1:Datetime must be at least to day. {$this is DateTime implies $this.toString().length() >= 10}
column39: OBX-14, and/or OBX-19 after v2.4  (depends on who observation made)

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column14: Date/Time this version was made available
column15: The date and time this version of the observation was made available to providers, typically after the results have been reviewed and verified.
column16: For Observations that don’t require review and verification, it may be the same as the [`lastUpdated` ](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/resource-definitions.html#Meta.lastUpdated) time of the resource itself.  For Observations that do require review and verification for certain updates, it might not be the same as the `lastUpdated` time of the resource itself due to a non-clinically significant update that doesn’t require the new version to be reviewed and verified again.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}
column38: OBR.22 (or MSH.7), or perhaps OBX-19 (depends on who observation made)

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column14: Who is responsible for the observation
column15: Who was responsible for asserting the observed value as "true".
column17: May give a degree of confidence in the observation and also indicates where follow-up questions should be directed.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}
column39: OBX.15 / (Practitioner)  OBX-16,  PRT-5:PRT-4='RO' /  (Device)  OBX-18 , PRT-10:PRT-4='EQUIP' / (Organization)  OBX-23,  PRT-8:PRT-4='PO'

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: The information determined as a result of making the observation, if the information has a simple value.
column16: An observation may have; 1)  a single value here, 2)  both a value and a set of related or component values,  or 3)  only a set of related or component values. If a value is present, the datatype for this element should be determined by Observation.code.  A CodeableConcept with just a text would be used instead of a string if the field was usually coded, or if the type associated with the Observation.code defines a coded value.  For additional guidance, see the [Notes section](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#notes) below.
column17: An observation exists to have a value, though it might not if it is in error, or if it represents a group of observations.
column37:

us-core-3:SHALL use UCUM for coded quantity units. {valueQuantity.system.empty() or valueQuantity.system = 'http://unitsofmeasure.org'}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: Provides a reason why the expected value in the element Observation.value[x] is missing.
column16:
Null or exceptional values can be represented two ways in FHIR Observations.  One way is to simply include them in the value set and represent the exceptions in the value.  For example, measurement values for a serology test could be  "detected", "not detected", "inconclusive", or  "specimen unsatisfactory".   

The alternate way is to use the value element for actual observations and use the explicit dataAbsentReason element to record exceptional values.  For example, the dataAbsentReason code "error" could be used when the measurement was not completed. Note that an observation may only be reported if there are values to report. For example differential cell counts values may be reported only when > 0.  Because of these options, use-case agreements are required to interpret general observations for null or exceptional values.
column17: For many results it is necessary to handle exceptional values in measurements.
column27: Codes specifying why the result (`Observation.value[x]`) is missing.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: A categorical assessment of an observation value.  For example, high, low, normal.
column16: Historically used for laboratory results (known as 'abnormal flag' ),  its use extends to other use cases where coded interpretations  are relevant.  Often reported as one or more simple compact codes this element is often placed adjacent to the result value in reports and flow sheets to signal the meaning/normalcy status of the result.
column17: For some results, particularly numeric results, an interpretation is necessary to fully understand the significance of a result.
column27: Codes identifying interpretations of observations.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile

column17: Need to be able to provide free text additional information.

column38: NTE.3 (partner NTE to OBX, or sometimes another (child?) OBX)

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile

column16:
Only used if not implicit in code found in Observation.code.  In many systems, this may be represented as a related observation instead of an inline component.   

If the use case requires BodySite to be handled as a separate resource (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension[ bodySite](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-bodysite.html).
column27: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

column17: In some cases, method can impact results and is thus used for determining whether results can be compared or determining significance of results.
column27: Methods for simple observations.

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: The specimen that was used when this observation was made.
column16: Should only be used if not implicit in code found in `Observation.code`.  Observations are not made on specimens themselves; they are made on a subject, but in many cases by the means of a specimen. Note that although specimens are often involved, they are not always tracked and reported explicitly. Also note that observation resources may be used in contexts that track the specimen explicitly (e.g. Diagnostic Report).
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile

column15: Guidance on how to interpret the value by comparison to a normal or recommended range.  Multiple reference ranges are interpreted as an "OR".   In other words, to represent two distinct target populations, two `referenceRange` elements would be used.
column16: Most observations only have one generic reference range. Systems MAY choose to restrict to only supplying the relevant reference range based on knowledge about the patient (e.g., specific to the patient's age, gender, weight and other factors), but this might not be possible or appropriate. Whenever more than one reference range is supplied, the differences between them SHOULD be provided in the reference range and/or age properties.
column17: Knowing what values are considered "normal" can help evaluate the significance of a particular result. Need to be able to provide multiple reference ranges for different contexts.

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile

column17: Need to be able to say what kind of reference range this is - normal, recommended, therapeutic, etc.,  - for proper interpretation.

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: Codes to indicate the target population this reference range applies to.  For example, a reference range may be based on the normal population or a particular sex or race.  Multiple `appliesTo`  are interpreted as an "AND" of the target populations.  For example, to represent a target population of African American females, both a code of female and a code for African American would be used.
column16: This SHOULD be populated if there is more than one range.  If this element is not present then the normal population is assumed.
column17: Need to be able to identify the target population for proper interpretation.

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column14: Text based reference range in an observation
column15: Text based reference range in an observation which may be used when a quantitative range is not appropriate for an observation.  An example would be a reference value of "Negative" or a list or table of "normals".
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column14: Related resource that belongs to the Observation group
column15: This observation is a group observation (e.g. a battery, a panel of tests, a set of vital sign measurements) that includes the target as a member of the group.
column16: When using this element, an observation will typically have either a value or a set of related resources, although both may be present in some cases.  For a discussion on the ways Observations can assembled in groups together, see [Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#obsgrouping) below.  Note that a system may calculate results from [QuestionnaireResponse](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/questionnaireresponse.html)  into a final score and represent the score as an Observation.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column14: Related measurements the observation is made from
column15: The target resource that represents a measurement from which this observation value is derived. For example, a calculated anion gap or a fetal measurement based on an ultrasound image.
column16: All the reference choices that are listed in this element can represent clinical observations and other measurements that may be the source for a derived value.  The most common reference will be another Observation.  For a discussion on the ways Observations can assembled in groups together, see [Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#obsgrouping) below.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: Some observations have multiple component observations.  These component observations are expressed as separate code value pairs that share the same attributes.  Examples include systolic and diastolic component observations for blood pressure measurement and multiple component observations for genetics observations.
column16: For a discussion on the ways Observations can be assembled in groups together see [Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#notes) below.
column17: Component observations share the same attributes in the Observation resource as the primary observation and are always treated a part of a single observation (they are not separable).   However, the reference range for the primary observation value is not inherited by the component values and is required when appropriate for each component observation.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: Describes what was observed. Sometimes this is called the observation "code".
column16: *All* code-value and  component.code-component.value pairs need to be taken into account to correctly understand the meaning of the observation.
column17: Knowing what kind of observation is being made is essential to understanding the observation.
column27: Codes identifying names of simple observations.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: The information determined as a result of making the observation, if the information has a simple value.
column16: Used when observation has a set of component observations. An observation may have both a value (e.g. an  Apgar score)  and component observations (the observations from which the Apgar score was derived). If a value is present, the datatype for this element should be determined by Observation.code. A CodeableConcept with just a text would be used instead of a string if the field was usually coded, or if the type associated with the Observation.code defines a coded value.  For additional guidance, see the [Notes section](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#notes) below.
column17: An observation exists to have a value, though it might not if it is in error, or if it represents a group of observations.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column14: Why the component result is missing
column15: Provides a reason why the expected value in the element Observation.component.value[x] is missing.
column16:
"Null" or exceptional values can be represented two ways in FHIR Observations.  One way is to simply include them in the value set and represent the exceptions in the value.  For example, measurement values for a serology test could be  "detected", "not detected", "inconclusive", or  "test not done". 

The alternate way is to use the value element for actual observations and use the explicit dataAbsentReason element to record exceptional values.  For example, the dataAbsentReason code "error" could be used when the measurement was not completed.  Because of these options, use-case agreements are required to interpret general observations for exceptional values.
column17: For many results it is necessary to handle exceptional values in measurements.
column27: Codes specifying why the result (`Observation.value[x]`) is missing.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column15: A categorical assessment of an observation value.  For example, high, low, normal.
column16: Historically used for laboratory results (known as 'abnormal flag' ),  its use extends to other use cases where coded interpretations  are relevant.  Often reported as one or more simple compact codes this element is often placed adjacent to the result value in reports and flow sheets to signal the meaning/normalcy status of the result.
column17: For some results, particularly numeric results, an interpretation is necessary to fully understand the significance of a result.
column27: Codes identifying interpretations of observations.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Imaging Result Observation Profile
column14: Provides guide for interpretation of component result
column15: Guidance on how to interpret the value by comparison to a normal or recommended range.
column16: Most observations only have one generic reference range. Systems MAY choose to restrict to only supplying the relevant reference range based on knowledge about the patient (e.g., specific to the patient's age, gender, weight and other factors), but this might not be possible or appropriate. Whenever more than one reference range is supplied, the differences between them SHOULD be provided in the reference range and/or age properties.
column17: Knowing what values are considered "normal" can help evaluate the significance of a particular result. Need to be able to provide multiple reference ranges for different contexts.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: Describes the intended objective(s) for a patient, group or organization
column15: The US Core Goal Profile is based upon the core FHIR Goal Resource and created to meet the 2015 Edition Common Clinical Data Set 'Goals' requirements.
column16: Goal can be achieving a particular change or merely maintaining a current state or even slowing a decline.

column15: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
column16: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

column15: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

column14: A set of rules under which this content was created
column15: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
column16: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: The base language in which the resource is written.
column16: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).
column27: A human language.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
column15: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
column16: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: Business identifiers assigned to this goal by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.

It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types.  For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.
column17: Allows identification of the goal as it is known by various participating systems and in a way that remains consistent across servers.

column17: Allows knowing whether goal needs to be further tracked.

(Keep in mind that different coding systems may use a "low value=important".
column17: Used for sorting and presenting goals.
column27: The level of importance associated with a goal.

column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: The target value to be achieved
column15: The target value of the focus to be achieved to signify the fulfillment of the goal, e.g. 150 pounds, 7.0%. Either the high or low or both values of the range can be specified. When a low value is missing, it indicates that the goal is achieved at any focus value at or below the high value. Similarly, if the high value is missing, it indicates that the goal is achieved at any focus value at or above the low value.
column16: A CodeableConcept with just a text would be used instead of a string if the field was usually coded, or if the type associated with the Goal.target.measure defines a coded value.
column27: Codes to identify the target value of the focus to be achieved to signify the fulfillment of the goal.

column15: Indicates either the date or the duration after start by which the goal should be met.
column17: Identifies when the goal should be evaluated.

column15: Identifies when the current status.  I.e. When initially created, when achieved, when cancelled, etc.
column16: To see the date for past statuses, query history.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: Captures the reason for the current status.
column16: This will typically be captured for statuses such as rejected, on-hold or cancelled, but could be present for others.

column15: Any comments related to the goal.

column16: Note that this should not duplicate the goal status.
column17: Outcome tracking is a key aspect of care planning.
column27: The result of the goal; e.g. "25% increase in shoulder mobility", "Anxiety reduced to moderate levels".  "15 kg weight loss sustained over 6 months".

column15: Details of what's changed (or not changed).
column16: The goal outcome is independent of the outcome of the related activities.  For example, if the Goal is to achieve a target body weight of 150 lb and a care plan activity is defined to diet, then the care plan’s activity outcome could be calories consumed whereas goal outcome is an observation for the actual body weight measured.
column17: Outcome tracking is a key aspect of care planning.

column15: Information about a person that is involved in the care for a patient, but who is not the target of healthcare, nor has a formal responsibility in the care process.

column15: The base language in which the resource is written.
column16: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).
column27: A human language.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
column15: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
column16: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: A human identifier for this person
column15: Identifier for a person within a particular scope.
column17: People are known by a variety of ids. Some institutions maintain several, and most collect identifiers for exchange with other organizations concerning the patient. Examples are national person identifier and local identifier.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: Whether this related person's record is in active use
column15: Whether this related person record is in active use.
column16: This element is labeled as a modifier because it may be used to mark that the resource was created in error.
column17: Need to be able to mark a related person record as not to be used, such as if it was created in error.
column19: This resource is generally assumed to be active if no value is provided for the active element
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: The patient this person is related to
column15: The patient this person is related to.
column17: We need to know which patient this RelatedPerson is related to.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: The nature of the relationship between a patient and the related person.
column17: We need to know the relationship with the patient since it influences the interpretation of the information attributed to this person.
column27: The nature of the relationship between a patient and the related person.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: A name associated with the person
column15: A name associated with the person.
column17: Related persons need to be identified by name, but it is uncommon to need details about multiple other names for that person.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: A contact detail for the person
column15: A contact detail for the person, e.g. a telephone number or an email address.
column16: Person may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods.  May need to have options for contacting the person urgently, and also to help with identification.
column17: People have (primary) ways to contact them in some way such as phone, email.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: Administrative Gender - the gender that the person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
column17: Needed for identification of the person, in combination with (at least) name and birth date.
column27: The gender of a person used for administrative purposes.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: The date on which the related person was born
column15: The date on which the related person was born.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: Address where the related person can be contacted or visited
column15: Address where the related person can be contacted or visited.
column17: Need to keep track where the related person can be contacted per postal mail or visited.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: Image of the person.
column17: Many EHR systems have the capability to capture an image of persons. Fits with newer social media usage too.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: Period of time that this relationship is considered valid
column15: The period of time during which this relationship is or was active. If there are no dates defined, then the interval is unknown.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column14: A language which may be used to communicate with about the patient's health
column15: A language which may be used to communicate with about the patient's health.
column16: If no language is specified, this *implies* that the default local language is spoken.  If you need to convey proficiency for multiple modes, then you need multiple RelatedPerson.Communication associations.   If the RelatedPerson does not speak the default local language, then the Interpreter Required Standard can be used to explicitly declare that an interpreter is required.
column17: If a related person does not speak the local language, interpreters may be required, so languages spoken and proficiency is an important things to keep track of both for patient and other persons of interest.

column14: The language which can be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health
column15: The ISO-639-1 alpha 2 code in lower case for the language, optionally followed by a hyphen and the ISO-3166-1 alpha 2 code for the region in upper case; e.g. "en" for English, or "en-US" for American English versus "en-EN" for England English.
column16: The structure aa-BB with this exact casing is one the most widely used notations for locale. However not all systems actually code this but instead have it as free text. Hence CodeableConcept instead of code as the data type.
column17: Most systems in multilingual countries will want to convey language. Not all systems actually need the regional dialect.
column27: A human language.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: Indicates whether or not the patient prefers this language (over other languages he masters up a certain level).
column16: This language is specifically identified for communicating healthcare information.
column17: People that master multiple languages up to certain level may prefer one or more, i.e. feel more confident in communicating in a particular language making other languages sort of a fall back method.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column15: For Observations derived from surveys/questionnaires.
column16: Used for simple observations such as education status, food insecurity observations, etc. This profile allows the representation of SDOH observations based on SDOH screening questionnaire responses (which can also be represented using SDC QuestionnaireResponse).

column39: OBX.21  For OBX segments from systems without OBX-21 support a combination of ORC/OBR and OBX must be negotiated between trading partners to uniquely identify the OBX segment. Depending on how V2 has been implemented each of these may be an option: 1) OBR-3 + OBX-3 + OBX-4 or 2) OBR-3 + OBR-4 + OBX-3 + OBX-4 or 2) some other way to uniquely ID the OBR/ORC + OBX-3 + OBX-4.

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column15: A plan, proposal or order that is fulfilled in whole or in part by this event.  For example, a MedicationRequest may require a patient to have laboratory test performed before  it is dispensed.
column17: Allows tracing of authorization for the event and tracking whether proposals/recommendations were acted upon.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column15: A larger event of which this particular Observation is a component or step.  For example,  an observation as part of a procedure.
column16: To link an Observation to an Encounter use `encounter`.  See the  [Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#obsgrouping) below for guidance on referencing another Observation.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: The status of the result value.
column16: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.
column17: Need to track the status of individual results. Some results are finalized before the whole report is finalized.
column27: Codes providing the status of an observation.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}
column41: status  Amended & Final are differentiated by whether it is the subject of a ControlAct event with a type of "revise"

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column15: A code that classifies the general type of observation being made.
column16: In addition to the required category valueset, this element allows various categorization schemes based on the owner’s definition of the category and effectively multiple categories can be used at once.  The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set.
column17: To identify that observation is derived from a questionnaire.
column27: Codes for high level observation categories.
column38: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column17: Used for filtering what observations are retrieved and displayed.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column15: A code that classifies the general type of observation being made.

column17: Used for filtering what that this is an observation derived from a survey/questionnaire.
column27: Codes for high level observation categories.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column15: Describes what was observed. Sometimes this is called the observation "name".
column16: *All* code-value and, if present, component.code-component.value pairs need to be taken into account to correctly understand the meaning of the observation.
column17: Knowing what kind of observation is being made is essential to understanding the observation.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column14: Who and/or what the observation is about
column15: The patient, or group of patients, location, or device this observation is about and into whose record the observation is placed. If the actual focus of the observation is different from the subject (or a sample of, part, or region of the subject), the `focus` element or the `code` itself specifies the actual focus of the observation.
column16: One would expect this element to be a cardinality of 1..1. The only circumstance in which the subject can be missing is when the observation is made by a device that does not know the patient. In this case, the observation SHALL be matched to a patient through some context/channel matching technique, and at this point, the observation should be updated.
column17: Observations have no value if you don't know who or what they're about.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column14: What the observation is about, when it is not about the subject of record
column15: The actual focus of an observation when it is not the patient of record representing something or someone associated with the patient such as a spouse, parent, fetus, or donor. For example, fetus observations in a mother's record.  The focus of an observation could also be an existing condition,  an intervention, the subject's diet,  another observation of the subject,  or a body structure such as tumor or implanted device.   An example use case would be using the Observation resource to capture whether the mother is trained to change her child's tracheostomy tube. In this example, the child is the patient of record and the mother is the focus.
column16: Typically, an observation is made about the subject - a patient, or group of patients, location, or device - and the distinction between the subject and what is directly measured for an observation is specified in the observation code itself ( e.g., "Blood Glucose") and does not need to be represented separately using this element.  Use `specimen` if a reference to a specimen is required.  If a code is required instead of a resource use either  `bodysite` for bodysites or the standard extension [focusCode](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-observation-focuscode.html).
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column14: Healthcare event during which this observation is made
column15: The healthcare event  (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) during which this observation is made.
column16: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some events may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter (e.g. pre-admission laboratory tests).
column17: For some observations it may be important to know the link between an observation and a particular encounter.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column15: The time or time-period the observed value is asserted as being true. For biological subjects - e.g. human patients - this is usually called the "physiologically relevant time".
column16: At least a date should be present unless this observation is a historical report.
column17: Knowing when an observation was deemed true is important to its relevance as well as determining trends.

column39: OBX-14, and/or OBX-19 after v2.4  (depends on who observation made)

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column14: Date/Time this version was made available
column15: The date and time this version of the observation was made available to providers, typically after the results have been reviewed and verified.
column16: For Observations that don’t require review and verification, it may be the same as the [`lastUpdated` ](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/resource-definitions.html#Meta.lastUpdated) time of the resource itself.  For Observations that do require review and verification for certain updates, it might not be the same as the `lastUpdated` time of the resource itself due to a non-clinically significant update that doesn’t require the new version to be reviewed and verified again.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}
column38: OBR.22 (or MSH.7), or perhaps OBX-19 (depends on who observation made)

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column14: Who is responsible for the observation
column15: Who was responsible for asserting the observed value as "true".
column16: Some questions on questionnaires are not answered directly (e.g., asserted) by the individual completing the questionnaire, but are derived from answers to one or more other questions. For types of answers, `Observation.performer` should not be specified and `Observation.derivedFrom` should reference the relevant Screening Response Observation(s).
column17: May give a degree of confidence in the observation and also indicates where follow-up questions should be directed.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column15: The information determined as a result of making the observation, if the information has a simple value.
column16: An observation may have; 1)  a single value here, 2)  both a value and a set of related or component values,  or 3)  only a set of related or component values. If a value is present, the datatype for this element should be determined by Observation.code.  A CodeableConcept with just a text would be used instead of a string if the field was usually coded, or if the type associated with the Observation.code defines a coded value.
column17: An observation exists to have a value, though it might not if it is in error, or if it represents a group of observations.

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column15: Provides a reason why the expected value in the element Observation.value[x] is missing.
column16: "Null" or exceptional values can be represented two ways in FHIR Observations.  One way is to simply include them in the value set and represent the exceptions in the value.  The alternate way is to use the value element for actual observations and use the explicit dataAbsentReason element to record exceptional values. For a given LOINC question, if the LOINC answer list includes concepts such as 'unknown' or 'not available', they should be used for Observation.value. Where these concepts are not part of the value set for Observation.value, the Observation.dataAbsentReason can be used if necessary and appropriate.
column17: For many results it is necessary to handle exceptional values in measurements.
column27: Codes specifying why the result (`Observation.value[x]`) is missing.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column15: A categorical assessment of an observation value.  For example, high, low, normal.
column16: Historically used for laboratory results (known as 'abnormal flag' ),  its use extends to other use cases where coded interpretations  are relevant.  Often reported as one or more simple compact codes this element is often placed adjacent to the result value in reports and flow sheets to signal the meaning/normalcy status of the result.
column17: For some results, particularly numeric results, an interpretation is necessary to fully understand the significance of a result.
column27: Codes identifying interpretations of observations.
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile

column16:
Only used if not implicit in code found in Observation.code.  In many systems, this may be represented as a related observation instead of an inline component.   

If the use case requires BodySite to be handled as a separate resource (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension[ bodySite](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-bodysite.html).

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column15: The specimen that was used when this observation was made.
column16: Should only be used if not implicit in code found in `Observation.code`.  Observations are not made on specimens themselves; they are made on a subject, but in many cases by the means of a specimen. Note that although specimens are often involved, they are not always tracked and reported explicitly. Also note that observation resources may be used in contexts that track the specimen explicitly (e.g. Diagnostic Report).
column37: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column3: US Core Screening Response Observation Profile
column15: Guidance on how to interpret the value by comparison to a normal or recommended range.  Multiple reference ranges are interpreted as an "OR".   In other words, to represent two distinct target populations, two `referenceRange` elements would be used.
column16: Most observations only have one generic reference range. Systems MAY choose to restrict to only supplying the relevant reference range based on knowledge about the patient (e.g., specific to the patient's age, gender, weight and other factors), but this might not be possible or appropriate. Whenever more than one reference range is supplied, the differences between them SHOULD be provided in the reference range and/or age properties.
column17: Knowing what values are considered "normal" can help evaluate the significance of a particular result. Need to be able to provide multiple reference ranges for different contexts.

column16: When using this element, an observation will typically have either a value or a set of related resources, although both may be present in some cases.  For a discussion on the ways Observations can assembled in groups together, see [Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#obsgrouping) below.  Note that a system may calculate results from [QuestionnaireResponse](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/questionnaireresponse.html)  into a final score and represent the score as an Observation.

column14: Related questionnaire responses or observations that the observation is made from
column15: Questionnaire responses or observations from which this observation value is derived.
column16: All the reference choices that are listed in this element can represent clinical observations and other measurements that may be the source for a derived value.  The most common reference will be another Observation.  For a discussion on the ways Observations can assembled in groups together, see [Notes](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/observation.html#obsgrouping) below.
column17: When an screening response observation is based on a survey question that is answered directly by the patient, Observation.derivedFrom should reference instances that comply with the SDC QuestionnaireResponse. When an observation is based on a survey question answer that is derived from one or more other survey question answers (as opposed to answered directly), Observation.derivedFrom should reference instances that comply with SDOHCC Screening Response Observation (e.g., observations generated from questions that were answered directly). However, references to other instance types are also possible.
